case_vignette: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a sensation of fluttering in his chest. He has had these symptoms intermittently in the past, but states that this time his symptoms have been persistent. He is currently studying for exams and has been drinking roughly 10 cups of coffee per day. His temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 115/60 mmHg, pulse is 124/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is only notable for tachycardia. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is obtained as seen in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

I have a feeling of fluttering in my chest that's been coming and going, but it's been constant this time around.

It's been persistent this time.

No chest pain, dizziness, or shortness of breath; just the fluttering feeling in my chest.

I am a 27-year-old man.
Do you have any history of heart disease or similar symptoms in your family?
You didn't provide me with that information, so I don't know about any family history of heart disease or similar symptoms.

I've been studying for exams lately.

I've been drinking roughly 10 cups of coffee every day.
Have you noticed any triggers that seem to bring on or worsen these fluttering episodes?
You didn't provide any specific triggers other than what I've already mentioned about my coffee intake and studying for exams.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
You didn't give me any information about other medical conditions or medications, so I can't say.

They happen even when I'm at rest.
Final Diagnosis: Probable caffeine-induced palpitations.
